12A.title: Introduction to Logic
12A.description: Syntax, semantics, and proof theory of sentential and predicate logic.

2.title: Individual Morality and Social Justice
2.description: Introduction to ethical and political philosophy.

295.title: Dissertation Seminar
295.description: Presentations by graduate students of dissertation research in progress.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study and Research
199.description: Enrollment restrictions apply; see the Introduction to Courses and Curricula section in this catalog.

301.title: Professional Preparation: The Teaching of Philosophy
301.description: Students will work as teachers under the guidance of a faculty member. They will attend lectures, guide classroom discussion, and participate in a workshop in teaching methods.

107.title: Moral Psychology
107.description: An investigation of central issues in moral psychology, such as: free will, weakness of will, self-deception, moral motivation, emotions, virtues, moral education.

190.title: Proseminar
190.description: A seminar-style exploration of some topic in philosophy. The students and insturctor will investigate the topic in a collaborative way, through discussion rather than lecture. Topics vary from semester to semester. Enrollment is limited to 15 undergraduate philosophy majors.

132.title: Philosophy of Mind
132.description: Mind and matter; other minds; the concept "person."

290.title: Seminar
290.description: Advanced study in various fields of philosophy. Topics will vary from semester to semester.

3.title: The Nature of Mind
3.description: Introduction to the philosophy of mind. Topics to be considered may include the relation between mind and body; the structure of action; the nature of desires and beliefs; the role of the unconscious.

100.title: Philosophical Methods
100.description: The course is designed to acquaint students with the techniques of philosophical reasoning through detailed study of selected philosophical texts and through extensive training in philosophical writing, based on those texts. Should be taken as early as possible after declaring the major.

25B.title: Modern Philosophy
25B.description: The history of modern philosophy from Descartes through Kant.

H196.title: Senior Seminar
H196.description: A seminar course for honor students in philosophy on a topic to be announced. Emphasis on the writing of papers and discussion of them.

98.title: Directed Group Study for Lower Division Students
98.description: Directed study on special topics. Please see the Introduction to Courses and Curricula section of this catalog.

116.title: Special Topics in Political Philosophy
116.description: This course is designed to deal with a variety of topics in political philosophy. Its contents will vary from occasion to occasion. Possible topics include problems in liberal theory; justice, desert, and responsibility; communitarianism, nationalism, and cosmopolitanism.

189.title: Special Topics in Recent European Philosophy
189.description: The course is designed to deal with a variety of topics in recent European philosophy. Its contents will vary from occasion to occasion. Possible topics include: further work in phenomenology and existentialism, the study of a particular text by an important figure in contemporary European philosophy, current French and German philosophy.

110.title: Aesthetics
110.description: Visual arts/literature and music. Form, expression, representation style; interpretation and evaluation.

H195.title: Philosophy Tutorial
H195.description: The department will designate a tutor, under whose guidance the student will seek to satisfy the thesis requirement of the Honors Program.

251.title: Directed Studies
251.description: Open to qualified students wishing to pursue special study or research under the direction of a member of the staff.

198BC.title: Berkeley Connect
198BC.description: Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through various academic departments, that helps students build intellectual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled students participate in regular small-group discussions facilitated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-directed curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel discussions featuring department faculty and alumni, and go on field trips to campus resources. Students are not required to be declared majors in order to participate.

186B.title: Later Wittgenstein
186B.description: A close reading and extended discussion of central parts of Wittgenstein's Philosophical Investigations.

98BC.title: Berkeley Connect
98BC.description: Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through various academic departments, that helps students build intellectual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled students participate in regular small-group discussions facilitated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-directed curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel discussions featuring department faculty and alumni, and go on field trips to campus resources. Students are not required to be declared majors in order to participate.
